text: I think that a lot of people look to
coke industries as that's our sugar
daddy I would be hard pressed to find
two things that are more important to
this community than coke industries and
and shocker basketball they could be
anywhere
but we're awfully proud they're here
Wichita Kansas looks like a company town
in many ways there are no shortage of
reminders that this is the home of Koch
Industries but despite the Koch family
patronage that dots the region the
company only employs a small number of
Wichita residents 3,500 people or
roughly one percent of the city's
population here at it's remarkably
unmarked headquarters which perhaps is
what leaves room for a diversity of
opinion about the political agenda of
the nation's second largest private
company and the state's sixth largest
employer Koch Industries has provided a
fairly stable base to the economy for a
lot of people and that's allowed them to
frame their image in a more benevolent
way than really what it is we get tagged
as a conservative right-wing company
we're not it's unfortunate that being
successful in business being a great
employer being a great provider of
things people value in the marketplace
makes you open to criticism we're
sitting in Charles Koch arena
okay this place is beautiful and I can
show you around a little bit they they
put a nice chunk of change into this
building
look at this Charles Koch arena this was
all coke see they did all this do you
see the name of Arkansas and the cokes
are linked nearly inextricably and as
the political conversation focuses more
on outside groups like the cokes
Americans for Prosperity the conflict in
Wichita reflects a similar national
divide we have had numbers of death
threats against Charles Koch and David
Koch they think we are this evil and bad
and we're not and we're not a lot of
what we're portrayed so I meet a lot of
that venom and invective and all that -
the national political theater in which
we're living now what I hear is we'll
look at all the good things that they do
for us I mean they're a big employer
they do Big Brothers Big Sisters they
revamp the arena at Wichita State
University they put money the zoo they
donate to this they donate to that that
is all just bells and whistles the shiny
little thing to distract you while they
are proceeding to try to change our
country into what they want it to be
I have no opposition to the cokes
putting as much money as they want into
the YMCA or putting as much money as
they want into our University so long as
they're not trying to influence
curriculum or putting as much money they
went into the Salvation Army and all the
other charitable organizations they
invest in it's the other side of what
they do with their money that that we
take issue with its the policies that
drive people into homelessness it now
depend on these charities that we take
issue with you know there's no really
prosperity here what do they go and like
you know my daughter who just graduated
from WSU was telling me mom what's
what's here I mean the biggest thing you
can aspire to do is work for the Koch
brothers and I want to do that so I'm
gonna have to leave the state in order
to you know to really do what I want to
do my brother and his wife both are
employed by Koch we're gonna all have
disagreements even within your own
family I tend to not engage in in-depth
conversations with my
brother in his spouse about their
employer the hope is that you could
disagree and still not want to kill each
other
